D0E982B48603485FB5743B2F2DF4740F.description: SSAGC.E.39.d: analyze limitations on state and local government that may be exercised by the citizens (e.g., the initiative, referendum, and recall)

F37623E35373408DA0CCD09F935290E7.description: SSAGC.E.38.a: explain an individual's due process rights (e.g., 4th, 5th, 6th, and 14th amendments) including such cases as Mapp V. Ohio (1961), New Jersey v. T.L.O. (1985), Miranda v. Arizona (1966), Gideon v. Wainwright (1963), and Gregg v. Georgia (1976) by comparing the similarities and differences of each case

2006E28FEB37428DA5FED0E9CB63BBE7.description: SSAGC.E.37.c: analyze due process of law as expressed in the 5th and 14th amendments, and as understood through the process of incorporation by analyzing primary and secondary sources

58EF21D1696340AFAF5951CEBC3C3548.description: SSAGC.E.37.b: define civil rights as equal protections for all people (e.g., Civil Rights Act, Brown v. Board of Education, etc.) by analyzing primary and secondary sources

B234D19BDF52455EAE1DB6F2208DE948.description: SSAGC.E.36.c: examine how John Marshall established judicial review through his opinion in Marbury v. Madison and relate its impact using primary and secondary sources

9902279F40A541DAA6E4AA27C817C2C2.description: SSAGC.E.36.b: explain the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, federal courts, and the state courts by analyzing charts/diagrams

F4BC353D863D4554811F841A52D3B855.description: SSAGC.E.34.a: compare and contrast the organization and responsibilities of independent regulatory agencies, government corporations, and executive agencies using primary and secondary sources

ECF617583F1A49B995DF3DFA6DE1F8A9.description: SSAGC.E.34: explain the functions of the departments and agencies of the federal bureaucracy

6E55E9AE62B947219287C81089DAA280.description: SSAGC.E.33.e: distinguish between the roles of the President including Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, chief executive, chief agenda setter, Head of State, chief diplomat, and party leader by comparing the similarities and differences of each role

9893892A515143EC9B533CD1F779CEAA.description: SSAGC.E.32: explain the process for impeachment and removal from office and its use for federal officials as defined in the U.S. Constitution

73B5C1F0B33943B6A4EEF26B98CB0FB7.description: SSAGC.E.31.d: compare and contrast the powers of each chamber of Congress (e.g., power of the purse, 16th Amendment, treaties, etc.)

29FAB51F7EE646D485464E5019E0932C.description: SSAGC.D.29.c: examine campaign funding and spending and the influence of special interest groups on elections including Political Action Committees (PAC's) using primary and secondary sources (including political cartoons)

1AF4BC85CEDE4313B7F7839710AB8E00.description: SSAGC.D.29.b: describe the nomination and election process, including primaries/caucuses, the general elections and the role of the electoral college

66E181FF782349579E3EFD2D4D5A1540.description: SSAGC.D.29.a: describe, using primary and secondary sources, the historical development, organization, role, and constituencies of political parties

DFB017057D254BA399D8CB1D5A81145A.description: SSAGC.D.29: demonstrate knowledge of local, state, and national elections

5B5BC2A0993F4752899E87814513EB83.description: SSAGC.C.27.e: describe the roles of Congress and the states in the formal process of amending the Constitution including analyzing charts and diagrams

5726A1A696D34574A95F6DDF6BCB3ABC.description: SSAGC.C.27.d: analyze the Supremacy Clause found in Article VI and the role of the U.S. Constitution as the "supreme law of the land"

B91F0E9B8EA2461EBCFA15A0E17C009C.description: SSAGC.C.27.a: explain and analyze the relationship of state governments to the national government by comparing their similarities and differences

317A82182CCA4753AB94B5CB65C9C18A.description: SSAGC.C.27: demonstrate knowledge of the federal system of government described in the United States Constitution

8C0414870D3D40959F7E3BF21F728015.description: SSAGC.C.26.b: analyze the relationship between the three branches in a system of checks and balances and separation of powers using graphs/diagrams

1545D7FCF1E847E99B2A0168E49BB534.description: SSAGC.C.26.a: describe the structure, powers, and limitations of the legislative, executive, and judicial branches as described in the Constitution including constructing an annotated chart/table

8E365F3031D14BD0ABB4F210BC4F8463.description: SSAGC.C.26: demonstrate knowledge of the organization and powers of the national government

326AEB739FF34DFC8095E34DE22AB9C1.description: SSAGC.C.25.d: explain, using primary and secondary sources, the similarities and differences of key ideas in the debate over ratification made by the Federalists and the Anti-Federalists, and explain how The Federalist and The Anti-Federalist writings resulted in the Bill of Rights

5B1111E2F6154DF68779A90C41977945.description: SSAGC.C.25.c: explain the fundamental principles of the United States Constitution, including limited government, through the rule of law, federalism, separation of powers, checks and balances, and popular sovereignty and judicial review  by using primary and secondary sources, and charts and diagrams,

CCF641FF258D4E84B80E5BAA375B56FC.description: SSAGC.C.25.b: analyze how the Constitution addresses the weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation, and the impact of Shays' Rebellion by using primary and secondary sources

9DCDF31623F4485BA4FB100B777970A7.description: SSAGC.C.25.a: analyze debates during the drafting of the Constitution, including the Three-Fifths Compromise, the Great Compromise, and the Commerce Clause using primary and secondary sources

57D5F79D3A44468AACE27DC7A9CE5647.description: SSAGC.C.24.b: analyze the impact of the writings of Hobbes (Leviathan), Locke (Second Treatise on Government), Rousseau (The Social Contract), and Montesquieu (The Spirit of the Laws) on our concept of government by using primary and secondary sources

A4A9B50B60DD4657AB200DFB65C0750E.description: SSAGC.C.24.a: analyze key ideas of limited government and the rule of law by comparing similarities and differences as seen in the Magna Carta, the Petition of Right, the English Bill of Rights, and colonial self-government

FE7577C1E9244AD486BF8B6C1E161110.description: SSAGC.C.23.c: determine how the role of the executive differs in presidential and parliamentary systems of governments by comparing similarities and differences using analyze charts and diagram

633FC7122C5548BCB27C2C2EF36C6D49.description: SSAGC.C.23.b: determine how some forms of government differ in their level of citizen participation, particularly authoritarian (autocracy and oligarchy), and democratic by analyzing charts, graphs and diagrams

A499D799297D41E2B92038A95A18FF0C.description: SSAGC.C.23.a: determine how governments differ in geographic distribution of power, particularly unitary, confederal, and federal types of government by constructing charts and tables

FCAA7BA48E9646CBB5458CF46B566827.description: SSAGC.B.22.a: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

67052EED5C8D4F84A4A737451CA43511.description: SSAGC.B.21.g: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

EC1A5E91442B4C7A9232A22AA3391A12.description: SSAGC.B.21.f: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

3020811D91BC4EC898260EF0DBF21B62.description: SSAGC.B.21.e: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

F4069D6C03CD4D59BD6920E0D86A72FA.description: SSAGC.B.21.d: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

F0D754D0D6B344E3B5F50B47C62D4A08.description: SSAGC.B.21.c: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

4E739CCF86084DE4BF74F9D1832C73F0.description: SSAGC.B.21.b: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

5FFD4B35B796489E993B4BB236C670BB.description: SSAGC.B.21.a: evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence

0577FDCFB5D042489DCE86A9F5D5EB31.description: SSAGC.B.21: check for consistency of information

C0744BF9CA9047D4B94BFDAD57C1B6A2.description: SSAGC.B.20.p: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

7B5A9603344A4BFAA532E7D770265379.description: SSAGC.B.20.o: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

D332B34F12674A1098DA988EA38EAD56.description: SSAGC.B.20.n: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

9F925AC76E57475B97D0C76784FFEB7B.description: SSAGC.B.20.m: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

4D1F0200CC124AF78698051DCD6C9DCB.description: SSAGC.B.20.l: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

6D756842DC874D4EA95CDFCBF3466EB2.description: SSAGC.B.20.k: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

3EC4329DFCA74D92A7439D973B07B4D5.description: SSAGC.B.20.j: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

04B78EF072E94FD1B24265BD246FF329.description: SSAGC.B.20.i: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by using words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

E8A672BABC3E43F7A94B01562426B303.description: SSAGC.B.20.h: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by introducing precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establishing the significance of the claim(s), distinguishing the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and creating an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

4A308C813FEE4DCDAC97A4C28EED533C.description: SSAGC.B.20.g: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

D34A9D2B61AA4D0EA69419748B929C21.description: SSAGC.B.20.f: integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources

F26611FCD9234BB1AFC818E97F28CAE3.description: SSAGC.B.20.e: evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information

B2E155D973764379B1352E1BAFAE6A3D.description: SSAGC.B.20.d: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem

2A2C616E4F0C4748BD505FC5416003F1.description: SSAGC.B.20.c: evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence

EB0E95E586A342769C06BFEE65CE58A0.description: SSAGC.B.20.b: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

48F10599EEE04C798F124551D2F84454.description: SSAGC.B.20.a: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

254274CA2D2A4490ACC080E2B4D0433D.description: SSAGC.B.20: write arguments, informative text, and explanatory text that determine adequacy and/or relevancy of information

5335AEF69A8745BE8FB7A5AB9B74FA9F.description: SSAGC.B.19.c: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

88BB01B5AF2E4AA786801D11D876D6FA.description: SSAGC.B.19.b: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

669E348664924F6EB307F65D2895AD04.description: SSAGC.B.18: translate dates into centuries, eras, or ages

24FF11F4AF454628A7673FF133D20240.description: SSAGC.B.17.a: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

930EE3933EE64C288B09159D9941242B.description: SSAGC.B.16.m: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

D509BCEC06A646A696352626209F8DA5.description: SSAGC.B.16.l: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

C12F5CCD07CF4D5987974F7CFEBB23FA.description: SSAGC.B.16.k: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

9D34A87ABADC43B1991271A00F49F373.description: SSAGC.B.16.j: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation provided (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

73ADD7CA4625470E90F552960AE52BD3.description: SSAGC.B.16.i: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

DC292E7B47004415B2E40B737865961B.description: SSAGC.B.16.h: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

8F46C8CE315C4699B0603D254E7D22B0.description: SSAGC.B.16.g: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

2063D88810104DC6BC40C72C2512C1B0.description: SSAGC.B.16.f: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from or supports the argument presented

DFF246DA5E0B474F86DF248FE14791BE.description: SSAGC.B.16.e: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by developing claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant data and evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both claim(s) and counterclaims in a discipline-appropriate form that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

409EB9753BD44F9D96C5CB136AD0F297.description: SSAGC.B.16.d: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

131FE706C7A04B7CADFCEE905FAB4659.description: SSAGC.B.16.a: determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas

9B652D3F90E14C46946FCBA88344FB47.description: SSAGC.B.16: write arguments, informative text, and explanatory text that draw conclusions and make generalizations

15D4BE27BA8B42A988465CF8990C559B.description: SSAGC.B.13.s: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

48AD2A24EBA445F1B6824E1B4852B7E9.description: SSAGC.B.13.r: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

EB47060E19D74D588AFB6475C00A264C.description: SSAGC.B.13.q: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

0E09CC03D4D84B19BA9607DC1EA2BAC4.description: SSAGC.B.13.p: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

92E70664E7204A4499A77871E7E7379E.description: SSAGC.B.13.o: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

6D9F9D4AA1924115880640F2F3098D02.description: SSAGC.B.13.n: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

6152EF69A79E45DE958D83011CC0D5CC.description: SSAGC.B.13.m: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

8BF80CAEAB934FBCA1EB39F883416425.description: SSAGC.B.13.l: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

DDC69DB9882F48FD96F72052C8AEB762.description: SSAGC.B.13.k: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by using words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

15C85CAB1A85493DAA319A3B7D70E861.description: SSAGC.B.13.j: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by introducing precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establishing the significance of the claim(s), distinguishing the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and creating an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

F7B9730C526847DB826AD3285383B80E.description: SSAGC.B.13.i: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

18A16536A52C438B94CBABC79B3C1184.description: SSAGC.B.13.h: integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources

CBBC79D500974373B838C48678C9B509.description: SSAGC.B.13.g: evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information

DC56BF53393146A9806B290E0CADA7DB.description: SSAGC.B.13.f: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem

7F122F03E53A44F4BDFCC4E3AA0641F5.description: SSAGC.B.13.e: evaluate authors' differing points of view on the same historical event or issue by assessing the authors' claims, reasoning, and evidence

C7FFCCD6E2CF4920BCD4F61DF4073C03.description: SSAGC.B.13.d: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

B2386D6901C741218D333700AC954C60.description: SSAGC.B.13.c: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

91705C3FA7844CCEA671C8B87160D6A6.description: SSAGC.B.13.b: determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas

61529F07F86744A8853CF695C0F43FED.description: SSAGC.B.13.a: cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, connecting insights gained from specific details to an understanding of the text as a whole

99252FCE3AA143149E99A3B5462051A1.description: SSAGC.B.13: identify social studies reference resources to use for a specific purpose

731CFE7EB1104863915A52115AA679DA.description: SSAGC.B.12.c: write routinely over extended time frames (time for reflection and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences
